I wanted to join the Air Force and become a Fighter pilot, but at the age of 12 I had to get glasses (near-sighted). That pretty much crashed my dreams of flying. The original inspiration was Tom Cruise in Top Gun. And I just saw the latest video he released about the sequel and the real-G force scenes in it.. And I just started searching for videos to watch others fly, and I stumbled upon this video.

You cannot imagine how much I related to you in the first 30 seconds (I didn't even get to apply because I got the application, read up the requirements and realized I'd be rejected).. and having watched this video, I have to say - I'm so happy for you! You're one of my favorite YouTubers (and people - even though we don't really know each other).

You're always curious, learning, and getting as well as helping others get smarter every day! And I'm happy you got to live your dream in some capacity.

I'm saving up to get my LASIK, and hope to be able to fly one day. I also hope to meet you one day, give you a warm hug.. pick your brain on a few topics that elude me, and maybe even become good friends! :)

Love all the way from India,

I had the same dream I always wanted to be a pilot. In 1991 I joined the USAF ROTC while in 11th grade and took my ASVAB and scored a 90. Now back then I had 20/10 vision and when the recruiters found out about my vision and my 90 score they were all over me for pilot. Of course I signed up for Pilot and had a fully paid 4 year college program through the USAF and would come out and go into Officer training school so I would be a Officer right away. Now for the problem I lied on my medical I actually have bad ears and was deaf from 12-14 years old which actually increased my eye sight to 20/10. Once they found out that I lied and never said anything about my ears they barred me. Not sure if the USAF is as strict now but back then they were. I now have Vertigo because of my ears. So now I play DCS World in VR flying the A-10 Warthog that I wanted to fly back then.

The bob weights are not the only reason you found it hard to do a loop. As you do a loop, you are slowing down as you trade kinetic energy for potential energy. That means less air moving past your wings, which then means that you need to deflect the flight control surfaces more to get the same turn rate. So at the top of the loop, you need to have the stick much further back towards your lap than you do at the bottom.

Young people with bad vision that want to be a fighter pilot need to make sure they get a military approved procedure.  There are a couple different kinds of vision correction surgeries and the form the AF uses is called PRK, Photorefractive keratectomy.  This surgery ablates the surface of the eye where Laser assisted in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK) ablates the inside of the cornea leaving a flap that never quite heals.

In 1961,  I was a crew chief on a F-101B. Every so often we could take a ride in the back seat. The pilots would have a great time  trying to put our lights out in a high G turn. Nobody could ride in that back seat and maintain their lights. It wasn't really dangerous to pass out because those pilots never did and always maintained control. They were some tough cookies. I studied the problem and it is all involved with getting the blood out of your legs and into your head. The pilot could not see me very well in the back seat. In a high G turn he was very occupied with not  letting a high speed stall ruin our day. I would pull my knees up to my chest and the more G's he pulled the tighter I pulled. I was compressed into a tight ball an never lost my lights. To this day I am sure that those pilots wonder how I did it. I never let anyone know what I did.

The shape of the loop seems to be because the most G you experience is when you are going upwards against gravity, making the stick resist you more. Once completely upside down the Gs of looping, pulling towards your feet, is reduced by gravity pulling the other way. So then, pushing the same force on the stick actually pulls it further, turning more sharply.

That is how I understand it at least.

To explain the clothoid loop, consider that the aircraft slows down as you pitch upward. Then, in order to maintain the same G force, your turn radius decreases. As you pitch down again and regain speed, the turn radius increases again. This is why the loop is pinched at the top and gentle on the sides.

Rollar coaster loops are also clothoids, for the same reason - as you get slower at the top, you can turn more tightly, which lets you slacken up the turn on the bottom and sides when you're going faster. This lets you do a loop without as high a max G.

Anyway, I now wear glasses after getting a bachelors in aerospace engineering (not masters but still lots of screen time) but I fly a T-38 with glasses on every day;  Astigmatism can be waivered. It's cool to see a different perspective on what we do all the time and take for granted, sometimes a lot of us lose sight of the "cool" factor and forget to have fun.
Whew! DANGER ZONE!

Just a note: what you did there, the cloverleaf, roll and loop, are not 3D manoeuvres. those are basic aerobatic manoeuvres. a 3D manoeuvre is mostly based around post-stall control; where the aircraft is flying on the thrust of the engine and employing vectoring -- not the wings.

Here's something that will put your brain on its side (literally). A basic knife edge pass. Sounds simple, right? It's anything but. Not only do you have to hold the wings near vertical; which takes aileron input to hold steady, but you have to also coordinate with rudder; which you have to hold over a certain amount to maintain level flight, and you then have to coordinate with elevator input. Depending on the aircraft, you either have to hold back, or hold forward to maintain a heading.

The first day was aerobatics, did split-S's, immelman's , and some high speed low level flight around the course at Reno. The second day we flew formation with a group of four T-28's and an A1-Skyraider (Sandy), it was amazing, we were so close I didn't dare key the mike to ask my pilot a question for fear of causing a collision. At the end of the day we flew in formation to the airport and did what they called a 3 second waterfall peel off with one plane landing on one side of the runway and the next on the other side three seconds later. So much fun, thanks for reminding me of my good flight.
